item.title: Welcome to join our Hackathon!
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
Curious about learning Dexie.js? Create a full-blown app using just web technologies Javascript, HTML, CSS without having to build a backend?

Join Dexie.js Global Hackathon 25! It’s an 8 weeks hackathon that starts on Valentines Day 2025 and ends on April 13th.

Read more on https://dexie.org/hackathon/

Rich-text editing with Y.js

With the next beta of dexie and dexie-cloud-addon available for test on npm (dexie and dexie-cloud-addon tagged @next), it’s already possible to use Y.js together with Dexie.js and Dexie Cloud to give your users a full blown text editing experience with compatible editors such as TipTap, Prosemirror, Codemirror among others (all that support Y.js).

Dexie Cloud Starter

The docs are still not update with how to store Y.js documents in Dexie, but our upcoming dexie-cloud-starter app will showcase it. This is also a nice starting point for making your own app for the Hackathon. Dexie Cloud Starter will be published on https://github.com/dexie/dexie-cloud-starter when the Hackathon starts (at latest). We might release it already on Friday 7th.

That’s all for now!

Have a nice week,
David

item.title: Status update
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
Hi!

It’s been a deep focus period since summer 2024 were the new Y.js support for Dexie and Dexie Cloud has been developed. This project became feature complete in October and since that, me and one of my wonderful customers is doing cooperative work on a new Dexie Starter sample app — an extremely simple note-taking app that uses tiptap text editor with realtime collaboration through Dexie Cloud.

This simple app also have full-text search of notes (using multi-entry index and lunr.js) as well as organizing notes into spaces and sharing spaces with friends.

It might seem that things are moving slowly with issues and feature requests as some other things have had to wait.

During the last and coming weeks, we’ll be quality assuring the Y.js support and deciding on how the API will be. Some refactorings are also being done but I hope to get all these goodies out as soon as possible.

Status update was originally published in Dexie.js on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.title: Dexie Cloud is entering Rich-Text Editing ecosystem
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
Hey everyone,

We’ve got some exciting news to share about what’s cooking in the Dexie Cloud lab. If you’ve ever used Google Docs, you know how cool it is to collaborate in real-time on a document. Now, we’re bringing that same vibe to Dexie Cloud.

Our focus right now is on integrating Dexie.js and Dexie Cloud to fit into the ecosystem of rich-text editors like ProseMirror and Tiptap by integrating it with the CRDT library Y.js. What does this mean? Simply put, you’ll soon be able to build apps where multiple users can edit the same document simultaneously, see each other’s cursors, and do it all in real-time.

We’ve already made good headway on this. Dexie.js now has beta support for storing Y.js documents on properties in their persisted objects, which means your Y.Doc instances can be seamlessly stored the way you are used to store any other type such as Blobs or strings, with Dexie.js. This feature is available now in an alpha version for those who want to take it for a spin.

import Dexie from 'dexie'; // npm i dexie@next
import * as Y from 'yjs'; // npm i yjs

const db = new Dexie('articleDB', { Y }); // Y.js is provided to Dexie here!

db.version(1).stores({
  articles: 'id, title, content:Y, *tags', // let content property contain Y.Doc
});

Dexie will create Y.Doc instances under the hood, so you only need to consume and edit them using a DexieYProvider. But react users will instead use a react hook for this (not yet released). Here’s an example on how to render a TipTap editor in a react component:

import { useDocument } from 'dexie-react-hooks';
import { useEditor, EditorContent } from "@tiptap/react";
import Collaboration from "@tiptap/extension-collaboration";

function TiptapEditor ({doc}) {
  // Load content
  useDocument(doc);
  // Open Tiptap rich-text editor:
  const editor = useEditor({
    extensions: [
      Collaboration.configure({
        document: doc,
      })
    ],
  });

  return <EditorContent editor={editor} />;
}

// A parent component that loads the article:
function MyContentEditor({articleId}) {
  // Load article
  const articles = useLiveQuery(
    () => db.articles.where({id: articleId}).toArray()
   );

  // Wait until loaded
  if (!articles) return null;

  // Check if article with given ID existed in DB:
  const [article] = articles;
  if (!article) return (
    <div>
      Article with id {articleId} doesn't exist
    </div>
  );
  
  // Render the editor
  return <TiptapEditor doc={article.content} />;
}

Dexie Cloud

Next up, we’re rolling this out to Dexie Cloud. Once done, any app using Dexie Cloud for sync will get the full power of rich-text editing and the Y.js ecosystem baked right in, with awareness of cursors etc. We’re on track to have this ready by October 2024.

We’re pretty pumped about what this means for the Dexie ecosystem and can’t wait to see what you all build with it. As always, we’ll keep you posted as we get closer to the finish line.

Stay tuned!

item.title: Keep storing large images, just don’t index the binary data itself!
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
I’ve got the question a lot of times: An app using Dexie.js is working fine for a while and then after a while the IndexedDB database has become slower and finally crashes. In almost all these cases, the mistake made is indexing large binary data or large Base64 strings representing binary data such as image data, songs or movies.

const db = new Dexie("myImageDB");
db.version(1).stores({
  images: '++id, imageData' // please don't!
});

A common misunderstanding seem to be that all properties should be indexed. Yes, IndexedDB can store movies, songs and images, but that doesn’t mean you should index them. There is normally no gain of indexing a picture, tune or movie because how would you use it in a where-clause?

db.songs.where('waveBinary').equals(x) // ?
db.songs.where('largeMovieData').between(a, b) // ??

I don’t think there are any good example of querying those large indexes. An equals-query could be valid, but then it’s better to store a hash of the data and index and query that hash property instead:

db.songs.where('songHash').equals(x)

Other good strategies of indexing image data is to have an alternate field along with the data. For example, if the image is analyzed by an AI engine, you could index the output of tags that the AI engine would see in the image, such as “cat”, “fur”, “water”, “spring” etc. Image searches could be done by querying the tags property in instead to find images of a “cat” etc.

const db = new Dexie("myImageDB") as Dexie & {
  images: EntityTable<ImageRow, 'id'>
};

db.version(2).stores({
  images: '++id, *tags, imageHash'
});

interface ImageRow {
  id: number
  imageData: Blob // stored by not indexed!
  imageHash: UInt8Array // MD5 digest
  tags: string[] // From image AI analysis, "cat", "water", etc.
}

IndexedDB does not put any limit on the size of the indexed field. I would have wished that the engine would throw when trying to store a too large entry in an indexed property rather than mysteriously get slower and slower and finally crash later on. I think I’m gonna put a limit of at least 2000 bytes in Dexie to overcome this issue with IndexedDB and help customers avoid this common mistake in the future.

Most enterprise database engines do not allow indexing columns larger than ~1000–2000 bytes including Microsoft SQL Server and PostgreSQL. I think we should introduce the same in IndexedDB. At least, I want to do it in Dexie.

Keep storing large images, just don’t index the binary data itself! was originally published in Dexie.js on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.title: We’re launched…
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
Today on march 27, 2024, Dexie Cloud has been officially launched.

From now on, everyone can go ahead and use Dexie Cloud, see announcment on https://dexie.org/announcements/2024-03-27.

Thank you all who have been with me and build apps on Dexie Cloud.

Lower pricing threshold

We’ve lowered the threshold to get up running with Dexie Cloud Production. Instead of requiring to buy a 100-users subscription for $ 12, it’s now possible to start small with 25 users for $ 3 / month. So as soon as you want some real usage — be it a private group of beta testers or real users, it’s not expensive to start. See the new pricing page.

Collecting more success stories and apps

Now the next phase is starting — I want to make sure to do everything to make you — app devs — to succeed with your apps. My vision is to have a new page on dexie.org where we can list all apps that are ready enough to be launched or beta tested.

If you have an app you want us to feature on dexie.org, please post me an email on david@dexie.org and I’ll start collecting info. Some selling text, description of the app and a screen shot would be marvellous.

Planned improvements of Dexie Cloud

I’ve started a project on github.com/dexie/projects/4 for the coming 3 months, where I’ve listed important improvements where 2 of them will mean a lot:

  1. Optimized storage of large files
  2. Rich-text collaboration

The plan is to manage all work item for the next iteration of development.

Spread the word

Please help me spread the word about Dexie Cloud to more people: in tweets, blog posts, forums etc. The journey has just started.

David Fahlander

We’re launched… was originally published in Dexie.js on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.title: Does Web Apps have a brighter future than Native Apps? I Asked ChatGPT
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
AI shouldn’t be relied on in blind, but one can still curiously read its answers. This time, the answer I got listed valid benefits that web apps give us in comparison to native apps and pointed out the shrinking gap between the two in terms of performance and features.

The Question:

How would you predict the future for web apps contra native apps? What has been the trend last 5 years?

ChatGPT’s Answer:

Over the past five years, the trend has leaned towards web apps gaining more ground compared to native apps in certain areas. Here are some factors influencing this trend:
1. Cross-Platform Compatibility: Web apps can run on any device with a web browser, regardless of the operating system. This cross-platform compatibility has become increasingly important as users expect seamless experiences across devices.
2. Improved Performance: Advancements in web technologies such as WebAssembly and progressive web apps (PWAs) have significantly improved the performance of web apps, narrowing the gap with native apps.
3. Distribution: Web apps can be easily distributed through URLs, making them more accessible and discoverable compared to native apps, which often require downloading from app stores.
4. Development Cost and Time: Developing web apps is often quicker and less expensive compared to building separate native apps for different platforms, as web technologies are standardized and widely supported.
5. Advancements in Web Standards: Standards like HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript have evolved to offer more capabilities, enabling developers to create richer and more interactive web applications.
6. Offline Functionality: With technologies like service workers, web apps can now offer offline functionality, blurring the line between online and native experiences.
7. Security and Privacy: Web browsers have made significant strides in enhancing security features, making users more confident in using web apps for sensitive tasks.
While web apps have made significant strides, native apps still hold advantages in certain areas such as performance-intensive tasks, access to device hardware, and leveraging platform-specific features. However, the trend suggests that web apps will continue to gain traction, especially for applications where cross-platform compatibility and accessibility are paramount. As web technologies continue to advance, the distinction between web and native apps may become less pronounced, with hybrid approaches and progressive enhancements becoming more common.

Does Web Apps have a brighter future than Native Apps? I Asked ChatGPT was originally published in Dexie.js on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.title: Dexie Cloud Launch: March 27
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
At last we have a fixed date for production launch: March 27!

It’s been almost 3 years since we launched the first beta of Dexie Cloud — the Sync add-on for Dexie.js and Cloud Service for Dexie.js that now will become available for everyone to take advantage of. A big Thank You to all you early adopters ❤️ for all your help, feedback, bug report and endorsements!

About Dexie Cloud

Dexie Cloud is a new solution for building apps using any front-end framework including React, Svelte, Vue, Angular, SolidJS or even dotnet (using DexieNET). Build your own data model completely using the well-known Dexie.js library and let Dexie Cloud take care of consistent, access controlled synchronization of both private and shared data to enable rich collaborative apps without the need of a backend. Read more…

Status Page for Dexie Cloud: https://www.dexie-cloud-status.com/

item.title: New Dexie Cloud Docs + sneak peak of Management app
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
As the production release of dexie cloud is nearer than ever, the docs have been updated to reflect latest cloud and client versions. The updated docs are:

  • the new REST api endpoint /users that allows integrations to manage their users — specifically the option to upgrade individual users to production.
  • complete docs on the Client Side API
  • JSX code example on how to provide a custom login GUI (requires latest dexie-cloud-addon)
  • Example app updated with a License Warning Notification to show your evaluation users that are about to expire or have expired and advertise them to an URL where they can request a production license from you.

New subscription model has been released

The new subscription model that was blogged about earlier has been released and all customer databases and their end-users were migrated in October. A management app is soon to be released together with the production service. Until then, the service will continue to be free to use for all customers.

At the release date, which as of current estimation would be in early december 2023, it will be possible to purchase a real production license and use the Management tool or the /users REST endpoint to lift their eval users into production accounts. A new blog post and a new newsletter will describe clearly what actions will need to be taken in at least 2 months ahead so that you will have time to take action. If not taking any action at all during that time, the service will continue but end users won’t be able to sync their local changes to the cloud until you lift them to production using the new management app or the REST API. They will still be able to login from any device and get a pull sync, but their changes won’t sync back.

Management App

In the new management app, you will be able to specify the licensing policy according to the new subscription model

That’s all for now. Expect an updated blog post and a newsletter (for all that have signed-up for the beta program) when the management app is available.

item.title: Dexie Cloud Subscription Model
item.dc:creator: David Fahlander
item.content:encoded:
Production version of Dexie Cloud is approaching but the final subscription and database management portal is the last piece of a puzzle to get ready before going prod. As the last pieces are being developed, I want to share what’s in it and how the subscription model will work for Dexie Cloud customers and how it can help you rollout your apps using various subscription models for your end users.

I’ve learned about use cases where customers wants various freemium or up-front subscription models for their apps while other customers will just release their app to a dedicated set of users without having any subscription model on their own.

Freemium models for Offline First apps

Unlike traditional apps, Offline First apps share a unique quality — they can function without a server — just that data isn’t backed up or shared with others. This is a perfect opportunity for Offline-First app vendors since their freemium version can offer the app forever as it is — just without sync!

Freemium model A: Subscribe to sync

  1. End user starts using their app without registering or logging in.
  2. In order to get the application data synchronized, user need to register, purchase subscription from app developer.

Freemium model B: Full sync during evaluation — subscribe to continue sync

  1. End user logs in first time (registers) with their app and get a fully functional app with sync during an evaluation period of a certain amount of days.
  2. When evaluation period ends, their app keeps working the same but without sync. End-user can purchase subscription to upgrade their account and activate sync again.

These two different models fits into different types of apps. I personally believe that the second use case could attract more users because it shows the full potential of the app directly.

Dexie Cloud End-User Management

Based on the use cases above and other feedback I got from customers, we’re building this user-level evaluation model into Dexie Cloud and making it configurable in the management portal — with a dedicated API to programmatically add or upgrade individual users and fully control seats and subscriptions.

App developers can configure their account to put new users into evaluation mode for up to 30 days without them occupying any of your purchased seats until you manually or programatically upgrade individual users. Wildcard matching of email addresses is also possible to configure in order to release your app to people within a set of organisations.

Pausable evaluation users

End-user evaluations can be configured to up to 30 days and you as a Dexie Cloud customer never need to pay for your evaluation users. If an evaluation user starts using the app for a few days and then leaves it for weeks or months, the evaluation will pause (unless you configure it not to). When an end-user evaluation period finally expires the user can still use your app offline (with sync disabled). Of course you can add additional limitations in your app when evaluation expires, but it’s not enforced by Dexie Cloud. I believe this pausable evaluation gives users a more fair experience and hopefully attract more users to try the application out and eventually purchase a subscription from app developer.

End-user production seats

For our service, we use a per-seat subscription model that will cost from approx $12 USD per month for 100 seats. Additional seats are purchased in packs of 100. Customer can choose whether to control the named users individually (default) in order to control cost, or to automatically add seats as needed. The subscription itself can either be set to be the purchased number of 100-seats (default) or set to automatically upgrade/downgrade as the number of seats change.

Seat count

Users are controlled using the management portal or the REST API. A new REST endpoint <database>.dexie.cloud/users (not yet released) will be used to manage database users.

  • Users can be of type “eval” or “prod” but only “prod” users occupy seats.
  • Users can be added with an “validTo” date, and if so, the seat won’t count after that date, (and the user have to use your app without sync after that date until you update or remove the validTo date)
  • A single Dexie Cloud subscription can be shared between several databases from the same Dexie Cloud customer — multiple databases can be connected to a single subscription, allowing to use the same user-ids in different databases and still only occupy one seat per user-id.
  • To reduce number of seats, database users need to be actively deactivated or deleted. Seats also reduce if users reach their optional validTo date.
